description: From a merger of two words:

The name for a loom weaving instrument, recorded from 1338, is from a sense of being "shot" across the threads. The back-and-forth imagery inspired the extension to "passenger trains" in 1895, aircraft in 1942, and spacecraft in 1969, as well as older terms such as shuttlecock.

entries.meaning: (weaving) A tool used to carry the woof back and forth between the warp threads on a loom.
examples: Like shuttles through the loom, so swiftly glide
My feather'd hours, and all my hopes deride!.

entries.meaning: The sliding thread holder in a sewing machine, which carries the lower thread through a loop of the upper thread, to make a lock stitch.
A transport service (such as a bus or train) that goes back and forth between two or more places.
examples: The shuttle bus runs to the airport on a half-hourly basis form the central station.

entries.meaning: Such a transport vehicle; a shuttle bus; a space shuttle.
examples: You're saying we take the parking shuttles, reinforce them with aluminum siding and then head to the gun store where our friend Andy plays some cowboy-movie, jump-on-the-wagon bullshit.

entries.meaning: Any other item that moves repeatedly back and forth between two positions, possibly transporting something else with it between those points (such as, in chemistry, a molecular shuttle).
A shutter, as for a channel for molten metal.

verbs.description: shuttle (third-person singular simple present shuttles, present participle shuttling, simple past and past participle shuttled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To go back and forth between two places.
(transitive) To transport by shuttle or by means of a shuttle service.
examples: Guests can be shuttled to a from the hotel for no extra cost.
